comment._content: The Captain Cook Hotel swallowed Mr J. Boyce's store and gave him the boot! Google street view: maps.google.com.au/maps?q=-33.860765,151.208045&sll=-...

comment._content: It sure did. We're hoping to upload some more images of shops soon -  it'll be interesting to see what's become of them.

comment.author: 7517447@N07
comment._content: It was torn down in the 1920s and this went up in its place.

comment.author: 7161314@N04
comment._content: Pretty sure that's the same building. Just with a new facade - the windows are all in the same positioning exactly, as is the divider on the roof. It's merely an update in style or 'facelift.'

comment.author: 29029178@N03
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Pubs of Australia, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
Sorry beachcomber I can't explain the growing or shortening pipe. However based on the licensee's name painted above the door, the date of this image is between 1887 and mid 1889. To me this suggests that it may be one of a series of images taken of buildings damaged by the Kent Street sewer construction.

The name of the licensee painted curved above the door is Louisa Leistikow. In the 1886 annual list for the Metropolitan Licensing District published in NSW Government Gazette No 430 10 August 1886 p5374, she was at the Forth and Clyde Hotel, Princes Street, Sydney. In the 1887 and 1888 annual lists she is at the Captain Cook Hotel, 33 Kent Street North, Sydney (NSW GG No 438 3 August 1887 p5075, No 416 10 August 1888 p5640) but in the annual list for 1889 Bridget Corcoran is the licensee and Louisa no longer holds a license in Sydney (NSW GG No 416 15 August 1889 pp5560, 5562).

The Publican’s nameplate above the front door is not a matter of advertising but a legal requirement. The nameplate was required from 1882 on. ‘An Act to remodel the law relating to Publicans and other Persons engaged in the sale of Liquor’ [Assented to 19 December 1881] Act No.14 45 Vic (Short Title: Licensing Act of 1882), Section 77 required that ‘Every licensee under this Act shall cause to be painted and shall maintain so painted in letters at least two inches long on the front of his premises his name in full followed by the words if he be the holder of a publican’s license “licensed to sell retail and spirituous liquors”…’  
This also suggests that the licensee had to be kept the sign up to date or face legal action.
JS
